name: Lazy Day Caesar Salad
description: This is an easy salad that’s totally doable on a weeknight. Wash and spin the lettuce dry up to 5 days in advance; store it in a zip top container with a paper towel.
recipeIngredient: 5- inch section (about 5 ounces ciabatta or similar type of bread)
1 clove garlic (minced and mashed with the broad side of a knife or put through a press)
2 teaspoons fish sauce or State Bird Garum (see link in Notes)
Leaves from 2 large romaine lettuce hearts (washed and thoroughly dried (1 pound total))
1/2 cup grated parmesan cheese (use the smallest holes on a box grater)

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Meanwhile, trim the crust from the break, then cut the naked results into 1/2 to 3/4-inch cubes. Put them into a bowl, toss with a sprinkling of kosher salt and 2 to 3 tablespoons of olive oil. Put on a rimmed baking sheet and bake for about 15 minutes, stirring midway, until crisp and golden. Cool before using.
recipeInstructions.name: Preheat the oven to 350°F. Meanwhile, trim the crust from the break, then cut the naked results into 1/2 to 3/4-inch cubes. Put them into a bowl, toss with a sprinkling of kosher salt and 2 to 3 tablespoons of olive oil. Put on a rimmed baking sheet and bake for about 15 minutes, stirring midway, until crisp and golden. Cool before using.

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, whisk together the garlic, scant 1/4 teaspoon pepper, fish sauce, lemon juice and mustard. Taste and tweak to make sure it’s pleasant. Whisk in the mayonnaise. Drizzle in the oil as you whisk to create an emulsion. Set aside, or refrigerate for up to 2 days.

Whisk in the mayonnaise. Drizzle in the oil as you whisk to create an emulsion. Set aside, or refrigerate for up to 2 days.

recipeInstructions.text: Leave the lettuce leaves whole or cut them crosswise into large pieces. Put the romaine into a large bowl and sprinkle on about 6 tablespoons of the cheese and some black pepper. Use your hands or tongs to gently toss and dust the leaves. Add most of the dressing and toss to coat well.
recipeInstructions.name: Leave the lettuce leaves whole or cut them crosswise into large pieces. Put the romaine into a large bowl and sprinkle on about 6 tablespoons of the cheese and some black pepper. Use your hands or tongs to gently toss and dust the leaves. Add most of the dressing and toss to coat well.

recipeInstructions.text: Taste and season with more dressing, lemon juice, black pepper or a shot of fish sauce. The flavor of the romaine will dictate your tweaks. Divide among salad plates. Sprinkle on the remaining cheese and if you like, extra black pepper.

review.reviewBody:
I saw this on your instagram and immediately wanted to make this. I used 3 Crabs brand fish sauce and it came out great! I added a pinch of sugar and a little bit of Worcestershire sauce to the dressing. I used sourdough (pre-sliced loaves from Boudin SF purchased at Costco) to make light and airy croutons, but seasoned mine with italian herb seasoning, dried thyme, parmesan, garlic salt, and pepper. 

I'll definitely be making this salad dressing again! My family and I are hooked.
Great idea. I still have to use a dash of worstershire though.
